BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Major snowfall is expected on Tuesday and will continue on Wednesday. The snow/rain limit will initially be low (800-1000 m) but will then gradually rise to the expected 1400-1600 m in the Dolomites and the 1600-1800 in the Pre-Alps. Therefore, the first snow will be dry and the late event snow will be wetter at least up to 2000 m elevation. 30 to 45 cm of snow is expected at 1500 m in the Dolomites (40-65 cm at 2000 m) and in the Pre-Alps 10 to 35 cm with amounts as high as 80 cm at 2000 m. The avalanche danger from Tuesday is 4-strong for spontaneous avalanches of fresh and often wet snow that, along usual routes, may reach even low altitudes. Avalanche activity will be widespread between 1,600 and 2,000 m above sea level, including along the northern slopes. Large avalanches are also expected sa Tuesday afternoon and by Wednesday. Frequent skidding avalanches below 1800 m altitude are also to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: By Tuesday afternoon, it is likely that expected avalanches could widely affect man-made areas even at sites not usually exposed to avalanche danger. These are medium to high magnitude events. Conditions for hiking and snow descents as of Tuesday are critical. People are urged to stay on open trails and to rely on mountain professionals for open field hiking. Visibility will be reduced with the added difficulty of spotting dangerous areas.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution. Backcountry touring calls for great restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Natural avalanches are possible, even large ones. They can penetrate deep layers and reach very large size in isolated cases. In steep gullies the avalanches can reach intermediate altitudes. Even single backcountry tourers can release avalanches very easily. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in steep terrain above the tree line. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, as well as at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain in particular at high altitude. The avalanche prone locations are numerous and are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
Gradual increase in avalanche danger as the snowfall level rises.
Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for great caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Up to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Friday above approximately 1400 m. The strong wind has transported some snow. The new snow and wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack. The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack above the tree line.
Over a wide area over a wide area 30 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Tuesday above approximately 1400 m, in particular in the Prealps.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will prevent a rapid stabilisation of the snowpack. Some snow will fall on Wednesday over a wide area.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
As a consequence of the precipitation the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase.
Without question, it is inadvisable to engage in backcountry touring.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area snowfall. Continuous warming. The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs represent the main danger. This applies in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
In all aspects large to very large avalanches are possible. The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects. In addition the barely recognisable wind slabs should be taken into account.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The fresh snow as well as the large wind slabs remain for the foreseeable future prone to triggering. Weak layers exist in the snowpack. The weather conditions will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: A lot of snow will fall over a wide area.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Very cloudy or overcast with extensive precipitation. Snowfall level rising from 1200-1400 m on all sectors up to 1600-2000 m, with the highest levels in the east. New accumulations expected between 20 and 40 cm on the Prealps and Orobie. Avalanche danger 4 strong above the treeline.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new heavy rainfall will increase and overload the significant layer of recent snow that has not yet consolidated; the threat rating will remain 4 Strong. The detachment will be possible with a low overload, especially on many steep slopes and in particular where old mantle is present (northern exposures). To the south, the entire recent snow cover rests, almost entirely, on unfrozen uncovered ground, a condition that will favor accentuated snow flow phenomena. Numerous natural avalanches, both ground and surface, of large and very large dimensions will be possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The new heavy quantities of snow expected will lead to a significant overload of the snowpack which presents very weak consolidation in the recently formed surface layers.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Very cloudy or overcast with extensive precipitation. Snowfall level rising from 1200-1400 m on all sectors up to 1600-2000 m, with the highest levels in the east. New accumulations expected between 20 and 40 cm on Adamello, 10-20 cm on the Rhaetian sectors. Avalanche danger 4 strong above the treeline.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: New moderate amounts of snow will increase and overload the recent widespread accumulations which will present moderate to weak consolidation on many steep slopes. The triggering will be possible even with a low overload, generating very large avalanches. Numerous large and even very large spontaneous releases will be possible, especially where snowfall will be greater.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The new heavy quantities of snow expected will lead to a significant overload of the snowpack which presents very weak consolidation in the recently formed surface layers.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution. As a consequence of the snowfall the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: 30 to 50 cm of snow will fall. The sometimes strong wind will transport the new snow significantly. Large natural avalanches are possible in the regions exposed to precipitation. The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 1800 m. This applies in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The avalanche prone locations are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind and new snow at low altitude. 30 to 50 cm of snow has fallen. The new snow is deposited on bare ground over a wide area. This applies in particular on sunny slopes, as well as at low and intermediate altitudes. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. As a consequence of snowfall and the strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form. The snowpack will become increasingly unstable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of the snowfall the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the often large wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area 15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1800 m. The wind will be moderate.
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant and generally at intermediate and high altitudes. They are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. The avalanche prone locations are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
As the snowfall level rises dry and moist avalanches are possible, but they can be large.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1600 m. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on the soft surface of an old snowpack. Faceted weak layers exist in the old snowpack on steep shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1800 m. The wind will be moderate.
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant and generally at intermediate and high altitudes. They are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. The avalanche prone locations are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
As a consequence of the snowfall dry avalanches are possible, even large ones.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind and new snow at low altitude. 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on the soft surface of an old snowpack. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. Faceted weak layers exist in the old snowpack on steep shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The large quantity of fresh snow and the wind slabs represent the main danger. Backcountry touring calls for caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of low temperatures, snowfall and the occasionally moderate easterly wind, a precarious avalanche situation will develop on Tuesday.
These weather conditions will bring about a weakening of the near-surface layers in the afternoon in all aspects.
The cold fresh snow and the wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant, especially on steep slopes. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible.
Backcountry touring calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
Natural avalanches:
Dry loose snow avalanches and dry slab avalanches are likely to occur, in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation especially on steep slopes.
Powder avalanches are possible, even quite large ones. They can be triggered in the new snow and wind slab layers and can reach as far as the valley bottom.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
25 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Sunday.
15 to 25 cm of snow will fall until Tuesday above approximately 1500 m.
The easterly wind will transport the new snow. The fresh snow and the wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack.
The wind slabs of the weekend will be covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise.
Monday: Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry avalanches have been released adjacent to ridgelines in all aspects. Since Friday in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain many small and medium-sized avalanches were released.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Little snow will fall on Wednesday. The danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution. Backcountry touring calls for great restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Natural avalanches are possible, even large ones. They can penetrate deep layers and reach very large size in isolated cases. In steep gullies the avalanches can reach intermediate altitudes. Even single backcountry tourers can release avalanches very easily. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in steep terrain above the tree line. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, as well as at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain in particular at high altitude. The avalanche prone locations are numerous and are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
Gradual increase in avalanche danger as the snowfall level rises.
Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for great caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Up to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Friday above approximately 1400 m. The strong wind has transported some snow. The new snow and wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack. The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack above the tree line.
Over a wide area over a wide area 30 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Tuesday above approximately 1400 m, in particular in the Prealps.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will prevent a rapid stabilisation of the snowpack. Some snow will fall on Wednesday over a wide area.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Disturbed weather with widespread rain up to 1800 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow will settle on a layer resting on unfrozen exposed ground. During the day, the progressive rise in temperatures will lead to rain up to the highest altitudes, with progressive humidification of the snow cover. Due to the weakening of the snowpack, releases and spontaneous releases of medium-sized and, in individual cases, large-sized ground avalanches will be possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Progressively humidifying snow cover during the phases of rain mixed with snow. On the southern slopes, snow flow phenomena are possible, with basal slips that will affect the entire surface of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming during the snowfall represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1800 m. The wind will be moderate.
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant and generally at intermediate and high altitudes. They are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. The avalanche prone locations are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
As a consequence of the snowfall dry avalanches are possible, even large ones.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind and new snow to low altitudes. 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen. The new snow is deposited on bare ground over a wide area. This applies in particular on sunny slopes, as well as at low and intermediate altitudes. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. As a consequence of snowfall and the strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form. The snowpack will become increasingly unstable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of the snowfall the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area snowfall. Warming. The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs represent the main danger. This applies in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible. The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects. In addition the barely recognisable wind slabs should be taken into account. These have formed in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The fresh snow as well as the large wind slabs remain for the foreseeable future prone to triggering. Weak layers exist in the snowpack. The weather conditions will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Weakly bonded old snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow and wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, above the tree line. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized.

Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in some places even by individual winter sport participants. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on west, north and east facing slopes above approximately 2400 m. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.

As a consequence of warming small to medium-sized loose snow avalanches are possible. In particular in the regions with a lot of snow more frequent small and medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible, especially below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 15 to 25 cm of snow will fall on Tuesday. As a consequence of new snow and wind the wind slabs will increase in size appreciably. They are prone to triggering.

Avalanche prone weak layers exist deeper in the snowpack in particular on steep east, north and west facing slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The conditions will facilitate a gradual stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations. The high humditiy will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack also at elevated altitudes. Gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are to be expected.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In the afternoon as a consequence of new snow and wind there will be an increase in the avalanche danger. Backcountry touring calls for restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of low temperatures, snowfall and the moderate southeasterly wind, an unfavourable avalanche situation will develop in the afternoon.
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant.
These avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. They are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility. Backcountry touring calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
Natural avalanches:
Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry loose snow avalanches are possible in particular from starting zones at higher altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
15 to 30 cm of snow has fallen since Sunday above approximately 1500 m.
25 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Tuesday above approximately 1500 m.
From Tuesday afternoon: The easterly wind will transport the new snow.
The fresh snow and the wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack.
The old snowpack is favourably layered. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions, depending on the infuence of the wind.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some snow will fall on Wednesday. The danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Weakly bonded old snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow and wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, above the tree line. Individual natural avalanches are possible, especially in the Ultental and in the Ortler Range. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Avalanches can in some cases reach quite a large size.

Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in some places even by individual winter sport participants. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on west, north and east facing slopes above approximately 2400 m. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.

As a consequence of warming small to medium-sized loose snow avalanches are possible. In particular in the regions with a lot of snow more frequent small and medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible, especially below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 15 to 25 cm of snow, and up to 40 cm in some localities, will fall on Tuesday. As a consequence of new snow and wind the wind slabs will increase in size appreciably. They are prone to triggering.

Avalanche prone weak layers exist deeper in the snowpack in particular on steep east, north and west facing slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The conditions will facilitate a gradual stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations. The high humditiy will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack also at elevated altitudes. Gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are to be expected.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming during the snowfall represent the main danger. Backcountry touring calls for restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of low temperatures, snowfall and the occasionally moderate southeasterly wind, an unfavourable avalanche situation will develop.
The cold fresh snow and the wind slabs can be released very easily. Even single snow sport participants can release avalanches easily, including medium-sized ones,, also on steep slopes. Backcountry touring calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
Natural avalanches:
These weather conditions will bring about a weakening of the near-surface layers in all aspects.
Dry loose snow avalanches and dry slab avalanches are likely to occur. From origins in starting zones at higher altitudes dry avalanches are possible as the day progresses, in particular medium-sized ones.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Sunday above approximately 1400 m.
20 to 30 cm of snow will fall until Tuesday above approximately 1500 m.
From Tuesday afternoon: The easterly wind will transport the new snow. The fresh snow and the wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack.
The wind slabs of the weekend will be covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise.
The old snowpack is favourably layered.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some snow will fall on Wednesday. The danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs require caution. Weakly bonded old snow is to be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes strong southerly wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines on north facing slopes. This applies especially above the tree line. Single winter sport participants can release avalanches, including medium-sized ones. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.

Avalanches can in isolated cases be triggered in the old snowpack and reach large size in isolated cases in particular on very steep west, north and east facing slopes. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found above approximately 2400 m.

As a consequence of warming during the day individual loose snow slides are possible as the day progresses, but they will be mostly small. On steep grassy slopes medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible, especially on sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some regions 5 to 15 cm of snow will fall on Tuesday. The southerly wind will transport the new snow. Fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers especially on shady slopes.

In isolated cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack, in particular on steep west, north and east facing slopes above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The conditions will facilitate a gradual stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations. The high humditiy will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack also at elevated altitudes. Gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are to be expected.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Weakly bonded old snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on shady slopes above the tree line. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized.

Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in some places even by individual winter sport participants. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on west, north and east facing slopes above approximately 2400 m. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.

As a consequence of warming small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized loose snow avalanches are possible. In particular in the regions with a lot of snow more frequent small and medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible, especially below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 5 to 15 cm of snow will fall on Tuesday. As a consequence of new snow and wind the wind slabs will increase in size moderately. They are in some cases prone to triggering.

Avalanche prone weak layers exist deeper in the snowpack in particular on steep east, north and west facing slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The conditions will facilitate a gradual stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations. The high humditiy will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack also at elevated altitudes. Gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are to be expected.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs require caution. In addition individual gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on steep shady slopes above the tree line, caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas. Mostly avalanches are only small.

On steep grassy slopes mostly small gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible as a consequence of the new snow.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Up to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Tuesday. As a consequence of the strong wind the wind slabs will increase in size moderately. They are in isolated cases prone to triggering.

In particular in the south only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The conditions will facilitate a stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations. The high humditiy will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack also at elevated altitudes. Moist snow slides are to be expected.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Disturbed weather with widespread rain up to 1800 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Very thin layers of snow resting on uncovered ground. Possible isolated ground discharges on steep slopes at higher altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Snow cover of small thickness, resting on uncovered and thawed ground. Possible snow flow phenomena favored by the progressive humidification of the snowpack due to widespread rainfall.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Small avalanches are possible in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Individual mostly small avalanches are possible above approximately 1800 m. This applies especially in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack remains subject to considerable local variations. At high altitude only a little snow is lying. At high altitude mostly small wind slabs formed. In gullies and bowls the wind slabs are larger. Some new snow above approximately 1900 m.
